Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) governed by \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Pz + Q \\), where \\( P \\) and \\( Q \\) are complex constants. We explore the implications of applying the Laplace transform \\( L \\) to \\( z(t) \\), defined by \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{z(t)\\} = \\int_0^{\\infty} e^{-st}z(t) dt \\) where \\( s \\) is a complex variable.

If we apply the Laplace transform \\( L \\) to the initial condition \\( z(0) \\), and then compute the solution to \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Pz + Q \\) using this transformed initial condition, will the solution \\( z(t) \\) at any time \\( t \\) be the same as the solution obtained by directly solving \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Pz + Q \\) with \\( z(0) \\)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform fundamentally changes the representation of the function from the time domain to the complex frequency domain. Solving the differential equation in the Laplace domain and then transforming back can introduce differences due to the properties of the inversion process and potential singularities in the transform.
